story:
Help Struggling Student in Desperate Need of Assistance


Here’s the story: 
I was recently accepted into my dream school: Acadia University. Since I was an acne covered pre-teen I’ve wanted to visit Canada, but that dream never came true due to financial issues.

My dad isn’t enthusiastic about me going away for college. He doesn’t live with me and my mom and he rarely visits or provides us with any kind of financial help. The worst part is he could help if he wanted to. He owns approximately half a million dollars in property, but refuses to sell any to help me and my mom financially so we’re basically on our own and struggling to make ends meet. He always looks into my eyes and tells me, “Invest every bit of money you have.” My question is, what good is investing if no one ever benefits from the money? I’m pretty sure he loves his property more than me, but let’s no get into that right now.

There is absolutely no money in my savings account, it’s all been used up to buy groceries, pay for school supplies, rent etc. My options are dwindling. Fast. I need help desperately. All I’m asking is that you share my cause and if you can, please donate. As little as $5 can help, but if you wish to donate more, please do.

My time is winding down and I need to get funds in order to acquire my student visa which can take months to process. This means the faster I get the funds, the better. My campaign ends in less than 60 days, but it’s not achieving the momentum I hoped it would. Things are going painfully slow, but you can change that. Just one share on facebook or a tweet can make the difference between me going to university or me being forced to work at some job I’ll hate. I’m begging you to share with friends, family, anyone who might be willing to help.

Also if you tweet about my cause, make sure to use the hashtag #KindnessforKaj. I’ve had so many disappointments in my life and I haven’t been able to enjoy the things other kids are privy to. It won’t hurt you to share and it’ll take less than five seconds. By simply copying and pasting this link for this page and donating or sharing, you can change my future forever. Thank you in advance to those who will help and if you do decide to donate, be sure to select one of the perks and receive a personalized card from me. It’d mean the world to me if you helped. Thank you.

-Kaj

He owns approximately half a million dollars in property, but refuses to sell any to help me and my mom financially so we’re basically on our own and struggling to make ends meet. He always looks into my eyes and tells me, “Invest every bit of money you have.” My question is, what good is investing if no one ever benefits from the money? I’m pretty sure he loves his property more than me, but let’s no get into that right now.There is absolutely no money in my savings account, it’s all been used up to buy groceries, pay for school supplies, rent etc. My options are dwindling. Fast. I need help desperately. All I’m asking is that you share my cause and if you can, please donate. As little as $5 can help, but if you wish to donate more, please do.My time is winding down and I need to get funds in order to acquire my student visa which can take months to process. This means the faster I get the funds, the better. My campaign ends in less than 60 days, but it’s not achieving the momentum I hoped it would. Things are going painfully slow, but you can change that. Just one share on facebook or a tweet can make the difference between me going to university or me being forced to work at some job I’ll hate. I’m begging you to share with friends, family, anyone who might be willing to help.Also if you tweet about my cause, make sure to use the hashtag #KindnessforKaj. I’ve had so many disappointments in my life and I haven’t been able to enjoy the things other kids are privy to. It won’t hurt you to share and it’ll take less than five seconds. By simply copying and pasting this link for this page and donating or sharing, you can change my future forever. Thank you in advance to those who will help and if you do decide to donate, be sure to select one of the perks and receive a personalized card from me. It’d mean the world to me if you helped. Thank you.-Kaj

story:
GLOW (Girls Leading Our World) Tirana is an initiative of Tirana Youth Center that provides tools of empowerment to 400 impoverished middle and high school girls in rural and urban areas. Peace Corp volunteers developed the GLOW clubs and have been successful in several regions throughout Albania. Although Tirana lacks local Peace Corp volunteers, this absence is not seen as an obstacle but as an opportunity to mobilize Albanian women volunteers.  

Last month, with the support of Peace Corp volunteers and the national board of GLOW, forty-seven women/future social workers, were trained to develop and lead GLOW clubs. According to data collected by UNICEF, gender equality is a new principle for Albania due to its strong patriarchal traditions, where Albanian society has traditionally been dominated by males, with women forced to submissive positions. Women and children make up the largest percentage of people living in poverty.  

GLOW clubs intend to empower the next generation of Albanian women in the areas of leadership and reproductive health, establishing a stronger sense of self-worth. Currently, there are 400 girls between the ages of 12-18 (in a total of 14 schools) and the only supplies available to them are what is shown (below.)  


GLOW is operating without any institutional support; these women have completed six training sessions, will host six club meetings, and will be GLOW certified by June 12th. Next week, we will start 15 new clubs. In the summer we will host 5 3-day camps at the Tirana Youth Center and we hope to include five new schools by September.

This is why we are asking for your help. No donation is too small. Our goal of $1000.00 will set the GLOW program up for an entire year, including 5 summer day camps and adequate supplies for all of the club members. It is imperative that this younger generation of girls are presented with opportunities beyond their country’s patriarchal influence. Empowerment is the heart of this program and we would be honored to have your support!

story:
ENGLISH VERSION/VERSIONE ITALIANA


INTRODUCTION

My name is Francesca Simi and I am enrolled as a PhD Student in the Ancient Heritage Studies Inter-University Programme of the Ca' Foscari University of Venice and the Universities of Udine and Trieste.

I am an archaeologist and my research project involves the investigation of human settlement in a specific area of Iraqi Kurdistan, in the heartland of ancient Assyria.

To achieve this goal I need your help!

This summer, I am planning to carry out an intensive archaeological survey in Iraqi Kurdistan. The main goals of this project are :

  • a systematic exploration in the site area of Tell Gomel;
  • an intensive survey of the surrounding micro-region; 
  • the study of the archaeological material recovered. 

Three surveyors, including me and a draughtsperson, will carry out the fieldwork.

The area around Gomel is of great interest because of its central position in the Navkur Plain, in the hinterland of the ancient Assyrian capitals of Nineveh and Khorsabad. This territory, with plenty of water and fertile soils, was a trade route hub from prehistory onwards. In later periods the area was strategic for commercial routes, but also for military transit and – in the case of the Assyrian Empire – for communications between the Turkish Upper Tigris region, rich in resources, and the principal Assyrian cities.

My project aims to investigate this crucial area, about which little is known, and you can help me to make it happen!


MY STORY

As a girl I always dreamt of being an archaeologist. I have a MA in Near Eastern Archaeology and I have just finished a two-year postgraduate specialization course focusing on Near Eastern archaeology. I studied and worked hard to reach my objectives and now I am happy to be enrolled in a PhD programme. I have taken part in several archaeological surveys and excavations in Italy and in the Near East. In particular, I  have already worked in Iraqi Kurdistan, an amazing land rich in history.

My research has its origins in the wider "Land of Nineveh Archaeological Project’"(LoNAP) which has been conducted since 2012 by the Italian Archaeological Mission in Assyria (IAMA) of the University of Udine. I have been a member of LoNAP since 2013 and I am proud to be part of such incredible project.

Now I hope to manage to carry out my own project in order to contribute to the understanding of such an interesting region. Not only will this improve my personal skills (and academic CV), but also it will also add to what is known about this area of Mesopotamia to which little attention has been paid for too many years .

My work will also help to protect and preserve the archaeological heritage of this land. This will be possible thanks to the creation of site distribution maps for each chronological period: all the information relating to the sites we identify (geographical coordinates, site preservation condition, etc.) will be shared with the Regional Directorate of Antiquities, in order to facilitate the protection of these archaeological sites.


WHAT I NEED

I need $ 9,000 to cover the following expenses:

-  4  return air tickets for me and for the other members of the survey team (2 archaeology students and a draughtsperson)

TOT. 3200 $

-  blood tests and residence permits for 4 persons

TOT. 400 $

-  two and a half months’ car rental with driver

TOT. 4.000 $

-  Supplies (archaeological survey tools, writing and drawing supplies, internet connection)

TOT. 1400 $

The Italian Archaeological Mission in Assyria will provide practical assistance (e.g. accommodation and meals for the first two-and-a-half months for the survey team), since the present project is framed within the more extensive “Land of Nineveh Archaeological Project”.


WHAT YOU GET

  • 5$ - I’ll give you a personal thank you on Facebook and Twitter
  • 15$ - I’ll send you a hand-written thank-you postcard signed by all the members of the project
  • 25$ - You’ll receive a thank you postcard and a pin with the project logo
  • 50$ - You’ll receive a thank you postcard and a cotton shopper with the project logo
  • 100$ - You’ll receive the postcard, the pin and the cotton shopper, plus during the fieldwork you will be updated weekly by e-mail (photo, video and journal)
  • 250$ - You’ll receive all the above perks, plus you will be personally thanked in my PhD thesis and you’ll receive a digital copy of it
  • 500$ - You’ll receive all the above perks, plus a hardcover copy of my PhD thesis
  • 1000$ - If you are so kind to help me with 1000 $, I will talk with you on Skype every week to personally update you and answer to your questions. I can also introduce you to the Director of the Land of Nineveh Archaeological Project and all the team members whose work you are so generously supporting


ARE YOU WORRIED ABOUT THE POLITICAL SITUATION?

Although Iraq is currently shaken by a terrible conflict, the region of Iraqi Kurdistan has remained essentially free of clashes. During summer 2014 several archaeological missions worked in the region of Duhok without encountering any particular problems or threats. I was in Dohuk in January-March 2015 and the situation seemed quite stable. 

Therefore, it is possible to continue working safely in Kurdistan despite the critical political situation which is affecting the region. Obviously, we will be in continual contact with the diplomatic authorities in the country in order to avoid any kind of tension or danger.

In this moment of shadow for Iraq's cultural heritage, I think that a new project working in this amazing land will be a true light of hope.


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Help me succeed!

Please share this project with anyone you think might support me – on Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, by email, telephone or on your blog.

 Please sponsor me and help make this project happen!


   CONTACTS

If you want to know more about the project or you have any questions, please contact me at francesca.simi@unive.it

Don’t forget to follow me on Twitter and Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/francesca.simi

https://twitter.com/francescasimi


THANK YOU!


****************************************************************************


VERSIONE ITALIANA 

INTRODUZIONE

Mi chiamo Francesca Simi e sono una dottoranda in Scienze dell’Antichità dell’Università Ca’ Foscari di Venezia (Corso Interateneo Università di Udine, Trieste e Venezia).

Sono un'archeologa e il mio progetto di ricerca si pone l’obiettivo di studiare lo sviluppo dell’insediamento umano in un’area specifica della Mesopotamia settentrionale, l’antica Assiria.

Per realizzare questo progetto ho bisogno del vostro aiuto!

Questa estate, vorrei effettuare una ricognizione archeologica intensiva nel Kurdistan iracheno.

Gli obiettivi principali di questo progetto sono:

  • un’esplorazione sistematica nell’area del sito di Tell Gomel;
  • una ricognizione intensiva nella micro-regione circostante il sito;
  • lo studio dei materiali archeologici raccolti.

Tre ricognitori, me inclusa, e un disegnatore, svolgeranno il lavoro sul campo.

L’area circostante Gomel è di grande interesse archeologico a causa della sua posizione centrale nella Piana di Navkur, nell’entroterra delle antiche capitali assire di Ninive e Khorsabad. Questo territorio, ricco di acqua e suoli fertili, ha costituito un vero e proprio snodo commerciale dalla preistoria in poi. Nelle epoche successive, l’area divenne strategica per le rotte commerciali e militari che la percorrevano e – nel caso dell’Impero Assiro – per le vie di comunicazione che mettevano in contatto le regioni dell’Alto Tigri turco con le principali città assire.

Per indagare quest’area così cruciale, ma ancora poco conosciuta, vi chiedo di aiutarmi.


LA MIA STORIA

Ho sempre desiderato diventare un’archeologa. Mi sono laureata in Archeologia e ho appena ottenuto un Diploma di Specializzazione in Beni Archeologici. Il mio ramo di specializzazione è il Vicino Oriente.

Ho studiato e lavorato duramente per raggiungere i miei obiettivi, ho partecipato a ricognizioni e scavi archeologici in Italia e nel Vicino Oriente. In particolare, ho già lavorato nel Kurdistan Iracheno, un paese incredibile, ricco di storia e tradizioni millenarie.

La mia ricerca si inserisce nel più ampio "Progetto Archeologico Regionale Terra di Ninive", condotto dal 2012 dalla Missione Archeologica Italiana in Assiria dell'Università degli Studi di Udine. Sono un membro della missione dal 2013 e sono orgogliosa di far parte di questo grande e ambizioso progetto.

Ora spero di portare avanti la mia ricerca per dare il mio contributo alla comprensione di questa affascinante regione. Infatti, la realizzazione di questo progetto non solo mi permetterà di affinare le mie competenze personali, ma accrescerà anche le conoscenze a nostra disposizione di questa area della Mesopotamia settentrionale che è rimasta finora praticamente inesplorata.

Il mio lavoro aiuterà anche a proteggere e preservare il patrimonio archeologico di questo paese. Questo sarà possibile attraverso la creazione di mappe che indicheranno i siti archeologici individuati per ogni periodo cronologico. Tutte le informazioni che potrò raccogliere in merito a questi siti (dalle coordinate geografiche allo stato di conservazione, etc.) saranno condivise con la Direzione Regionale delle Antichità del Kurdistan Iracheno in modo da renderne possibile la tutela.


DI COSA HO BISOGNO

Ho bisogno di 9.000 $ per fare fronte alle seguenti spese:

-  4 biglietti aerei andata e ritorno per me e gli altri membri della squadra (due studenti di archeologia e un disegnatore)

TOT. 3200 $

-  Analisi mediche obbligatorie e permesso di soggiorno per 4 persone

TOT. 400 $

-  Noleggio di un veicolo con autista per due mesi e mezzo

TOT. 4.000 $

-  Attrezzatura (strumenti per la ricognizione archeologica, cancelleria, strumenti per il disegno, connessione internet)

TOT. 1400 $

La Missione Archeologica Italiana in Assiria contribuirà generosamente fornendo assistenza pratica sul luogo (es. vitto e alloggio per tutta la squadra, per due mesi e mezzo), in quanto questo progetto è inquadrato nel più vasto "Progetto Archeologico Regionale Terra di Ninive".


COSA RICEVERETE IN CAMBIO

  • 5$ Riceverete un ringraziamento personale su Facebook e Twitter
  • 15$ Riceverete una cartolina di ringraziamento firmata da tutti i membri del progetto
  • 25$ Riceverete una cartolina di ringraziamento e una spilla con il logo del progetto.
  • 50$ Riceverete una cartolina di ringraziamento e una borsa in cotone con il logo del progetto.
  • 100$ Riceverete la cartolina, la spilla e la borsa di cotone, e sarete aggiornati settimanalmente (video, foto e diario) durante il nostro lavoro sul campo.
  • 250$ Riceverete tutte le ricompense precedenti, sarete ringraziati personalmente nella mia tesi di dottorato e riceverete una copia digitale.
  • 500$ Riceverete tutte le ricompense presentate, più una copia rilegata della mia tesi di dottorato.
  • 1000$ Riceverete tutte le ricompense, in più potremo parlare su skype ogni settimana; in questo modo potrò aggiornarvi personalmente e rispondere alle vostre domande. Vi presenterò anche il Direttore del Progetto Archeologico Regionale Terra di Ninive e tutti i membri della squadra il cui lavoro state così generosamente sostenendo.


SICUREZZA E SITUAZIONE POLITICA

Anche se l'Iraq è attualmente scosso da un conflitto terribile, la regione del Kurdistan Iracheno è rimasta sostanzialmente priva di scontri. Durante l'estate 2014 diverse missioni archeologiche hanno lavorato nella regione di Dohuk senza incontrare particolari problemi o minacce. Io sono stata a Dohuk nel periodo tra gennaio e marzo 2015 e la situazione sembrava abbastanza stabile. 

Pertanto, è possibile continuare a lavorare in sicurezza in Kurdistan nonostante la  situazione politica critica della regione. Ovviamente, saremo sempre in contatto con le autorità diplomatiche sia locali che italiane, al fine di evitare qualsiasi tipo di tensione o pericolo.

In questo momento di oscurità per il patrimonio culturale dell'Iraq, penso che un nuovo progetto di ricerca in questa terra straordinaria possa rappresentare una vera luce di speranza.


ALTRI MODI IN CUI MI POTETE AIUTARE

Aiutatemi a realizzare il mio progetto di ricerca!

Per favore, aiutatemi condividendo questo progetto su Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, parlandone sul vostro blog, o inviando questo link per mail. Sponsorizzatemi e aiutatemi a raccogliere i 9000 $ necessari!


  CONTATTI

Se volete maggiori informazioni sul progetto o avete qualche domanda, per favore contattatemi all'indirizzo di posta elettronica francesca.simi@unive.it

Non dimenticatevi di seguirmi anche su Twitter e Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/francesca.simi

https://twitter.com/francescasimi


GRAZIE!

50$ Riceverete una cartolina
di ringraziamento e una borsa in cotone con il logo del progetto.


100$ Riceverete la cartolina, la spilla e la borsa
di cotone, e sarete aggiornati settimanalmente (video, foto e diario) durante
il nostro lavoro sul campo.


250$ Riceverete tutte le ricompense precedenti, sarete
ringraziati personalmente nella mia tesi di dottorato e riceverete una copia
digitale.


500$ Riceverete tutte le
ricompense presentate, più una copia rilegata della mia tesi di dottorato.


1000$ Riceverete tutte le ricompense, in più potremo
parlare su skype ogni settimana; in questo modo potrò aggiornarvi personalmente
e rispondere alle vostre domande. Vi presenterò anche il Direttore del Progetto
Archeologico Regionale Terra di Ninive e tutti i membri della squadra il cui
lavoro state così generosamente sostenendo.







SICUREZZA E SITUAZIONE POLITICA
Anche se l'Iraq è attualmente
scosso da un conflitto terribile, la regione del Kurdistan Iracheno è rimasta
sostanzialmente priva di scontri. Durante l'estate 2014 diverse missioni
archeologiche hanno lavorato nella regione di Dohuk senza incontrare
particolari problemi o minacce. Io sono stata a Dohuk nel periodo tra gennaio e marzo
2015 e la situazione sembrava abbastanza stabile. 
Pertanto, è possibile
continuare a lavorare in sicurezza in Kurdistan nonostante la  situazione
politica critica della regione. Ovviamente, saremo sempre in contatto con le autorità
diplomatiche sia locali che italiane, al fine di evitare qualsiasi tipo di
tensione o pericolo.


In questo momento di oscurità per il
patrimonio culturale dell'Iraq, penso che un nuovo progetto di ricerca in questa
terra straordinaria possa rappresentare una vera luce di speranza.
ALTRI MODI IN CUI MI POTETE AIUTARE
Aiutatemi a realizzare il mio
progetto di ricerca!
Per favore, aiutatemi
condividendo questo progetto su Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, parlandone sul
vostro blog, o inviando questo link per mail. Sponsorizzatemi e aiutatemi a
raccogliere i 9000 $ necessari!



  CONTATTI

Se volete maggiori informazioni
sul progetto o avete qualche domanda, per favore contattatemi all'indirizzo di posta elettronica francesca.simi@unive.it
Non dimenticatevi di seguirmi
anche su Twitter e Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/francesca.simi
https://twitter.com/francescasimi

GRAZIE!

story:
Introduction

It’s not that often you get to make a modest donation and know you are not only changing a single life, but perhaps an entire generation. 

My name is Mary Daley Yerrick. I am a co-founder of Vital Voices, a non-profit that advances women leaders throughout the world.  I am a social entrepreneur and a proud member of the Education & Empowerment of Women & Girls Campaign organized by Sandra Kasonso in the country of Zambia on the continent of Africa. 

Sandra came into my life in 2007 when Vital Voices Global Partnership hosted an Africa Summit for Women's Leadership in Cape Town that brought together women from all over Africa. Attending were women who had a burning desire for positive change for women and girls, but needed a plan.  Education was at the core of their plan. Education could lead the way to economic empowerment. Nelson Mandela said “Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world.” 

Sandra embraced the theme of the Summit. She knew change needed to come for the poorest women and girls of Zambia. She had an idea. She knew that these women had very limited education and no financial resources, but they needed to break the cycle of poverty for the sake of their children. She wanted to help by teaching them a traditional Zambian skill that she could oversee and ultimately use to empower the women to improve the future for their family. It was “beading.” She would buy the raw materials, design the products and employ the women to bead the various products. Then, she would take them to market and sell them. 

They didn’t make a lot of money, but it was enough to begin their transition. She found out that the most important reason they wanted to have money was so that their children could go to school which requires a fee and the purchase of uniforms and books. It was unaffordable for most poor mothers. The fee was $150 and Sandra had a goal of raising that much for each of the women and then take it forward from there. She was successful, thanks in part to an Artisan Entrepreneur training conducted by Vital Voices in various locations throughout Africa. I designed and participated in the training and ExxonMobil funded it.

It has been one of the most gratifying things I have ever done. And, now, I want to do more to help Sandra and the women and girls she is helping change their lives for good.  What follows is Sandra's story about her journey to educate and empower females in Zambia to achieve a much better future. 

Why we exist!

Magic Hands of Africa was created as a "social business" to help uplift the lives of women and girls living in poor communities in Zambia, Africa, through making and selling beaded crafts!  NOTE: A "social business" for those unfamiliar with the term is one created and designed to address a social problem, i.e. poverty, in a self-sustainable way with profits reinvested in the business itself.  

In the past, our women “beaders" lived on less than US$1 a day and struggled to pay the required fees to keep their children in school, feed their families, provide shelter and pay medical bills. Magic Hands of Africa began with a mission to supplement the income of single mothers and help them meet their critical needs. It began in 2007 after the founder, Sandra N. Kasonso, attended a Vital Voices Global Partnership Africa Summit, held in Cape Town, South Africa. After networking and being mentored by various women social entrepreneurs from other countries, she returned home fired up and inspired to turn her one-woman beading business into a social business that employed, or better yet, partnered with ten impoverished Zambian women, trained them in beading skills, bought and gave them the supplies to make the finished products, which she would ultimately sell to local and international customers. The group of ten women workers soon grew to forty! The products were beautiful, fashionable and high quality.  As a result, the income derived helped the women pay for school fees and provide food for their families. YAY!


The challenge that led us here!


In 2010, however, as the economy dipped, sales began to dwindle and Sandra was forced to cut costs. It was heartbreaking for her to turn away the women who had once relied on her, knowing she was not now able to help mother’s pay their children's school fees. But, her passion kept burning within her -- she wanted to help these mothers, and she refused to  give up. She sought ways to improve and sustain her business model and went through various business management trainings. Happily, she has has now reached a point where she feels more empowered with knowledge and a determination to succeed. Her only challenge now is a lack of start-up funds, and is hence turning to crowdfunding to seek your support to help her revive her new and better social business.  

Why fund us?

       Mailess Tembo with her grandmother. Mailess was educated using funds raised from sales of our beaded products. She completed high school recently and is the first in her family to do so!


By helping to fund this program, you will help Sandra achieve her 2015 goal of educating 40 girls and empowering 10 women with US$150 grants to be invested in their alternative  small businesses, like selling produce by the side of the road, so that during slow sale periods at Magic Hands of Africa, the women will not be affected because they will be running their own successful small businesses. 

The ten women will be personally mentored by Sandra who will explore with them their interests in other income-generating pursuits in the informal job sector. Their progress will be documented and shared on Magic Hands of Africa social media platforms (Facebook, Instagram, WordPress and Pinterest). 

The women constantly tell Sandra how the beading business has helped their families. One woman, named Royce, said her teenage son once remarked "Mum, what would have happened to me had you not been beading? Would I have completed my high school?"

Help Sandra keep her dream alive by growing her new and improved beading business to help more women and girls have a brighter future.

Note:  Donors may remain anonymous, if they prefer.  


What you get for funding us!


First, you will receive a big heartfelt thank you and then you will receive these beautiful handmade beaded lanyards made by our women! But that's not all, we have more perks in our gallery for you to choose from all handmade with love by our Zambian women! We have other beaded items like necklaces, keyrings, Christmas ornaments, the lovely bracelets pictured at the top of this post and many other perks demanding on the size of your donation. Just visit our gallery and check out products listed as perks!


How your gift will make a difference

Offer US$150 individual grants to 10 women  

(if  we raise more, we will make more than 10 women happy!)       - $1,500

Training costs & field visits                                                                    -$1,000

Pay school fees and uniforms for 40 girls                                          - $9,000

Pay one year rentals for a small store & create an online store     - $4,800

One of the biggest challenges was failing to have a retail store that customers could regularly visit any day of the week to buy our products. Sales were mainly done at weekly craft markets.

Import high quality raw materials e.g. Czech beads etc                  - $2,500 

Lack of high quality raw materials is another challenge that contributed to poor sales. The local suppliers have poor quality materials which end product appeal.

Professional Photography Equipment                                                   -$1,600

Investing in a good camera, good lighting and professional backdrops, as well as occasional models…will not only help us capture beautiful images of our products, but also the progress made by our women and girls. BONUS:  It can also provide another source of income for the business so it’s not totally reliant on revenue from beaded crafts. People in the community could hire us to photograph their events.

Marketing & social media campaigns to increase sales                     -$600

Total                                                                                                              -$21,000


What are the risks and challenges?

One way we will address the issue of sustainability for the women is by encouraging them to create a savings group/account where they will save part of their revenue from their small businesses which they can later take out as “rainy day” loans to reinvest in and grow their businesses. 

Camera can also be used to help raise funds for the business…especially in slow sales months such as January-March and will help us maximize our Return on Investment (ROI).


What is the #5000Keyrings campaign?


The campaign was created in January 2015 as part of a new year's resolution to revive the social business as well as raise funds to educate 40 girls and empower ten women with US$150 grants to invest in their small businesses. The goal is to make and sell 5,000 keyrings to various individuals and organisations seeking fair trade handcrafted gifts to give their clients.
This campaign is ongoing and funds raised on Indiegogo, will help speed up production and buy high quality raw materials. Since January 2015, only about 400 keyrings have been sold. Another way you can support Magic Hands of Africa is by making bulk orders for your organisation to give as gifts to your clients.
 


Other ways you can help!

Beyond supporting the campaign with a meaningful contribution, there are other ways you can have an impact:

Spread the word! Pass on this campaign to people you know through emails, via whataspp and social media. The more people who join our community, the more women and girls Magic Hands of Africa can reach. Use Indiegogo’s share tools to make it easy.

Follow us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/pages/Magic-Hands-of-A...)  and Instagram (https://instagram.com/magichandsofafrica/)! When you share on social media please use the hashtag #5000Keyrings 

Thank you for everything you do in helping us meet our campaign goal.

Sandra & The Magic Hands of Africa women!

story:
Short Summary

We are team Eruditio, students of Hult International Business School in San Francisco.

Do you know that there are over 63 million children between the ages of 0 to 6 who are out of school and might never get the opportunity to receive an education worthy of giving them a chance at having a better future? Yes! there are and that is the problem we have joined in the quest to solve. The inequality growing at a rapid rate and the sad part of it is that people living at the "Bottom of the Pyramid" in developing countries aren't given a fair chance of improving their lives.

For this reason, we saw the Hult Prize competition as an opportunity to help in improving the lives of people that need it the most.

ABOUT US: We believe our team has the qualification to succeed because we are all from different backgrounds and we have the passion for the project.

Kristin is a German MBA student who has a Bachelor's degree in Economics and Business administration with years of experience working it different corporate organizations. With her experience, we believe we can create a scalable business.

Nuria is from Spain. She is a Marketing and Communications professional with 8 years of experience working in the Luxury and Fashion field. Her professional skills are focused on Strategy and development of projects, in order to sell a brand to the consumer with a detailed planning. She has a Bachelors degree in Journalism, a Masters in Communication and she is currently in the Hult Master of International Marketing. We believe that with her skill set, we will be able to have the right branding and marketing strategy for our business.

Aleksandra is from Bulgaria and has a Bachelor's and a Master's degree in Law. Prior to She had worked in workshops for kids with Down syndrome and also charitable work with orphanage homes. Her extensive work experience as a legal practitioner is beneficial to our team because she can approach the task from a legal aspect.

Last but not the least, we have Emi from Nigeria (our first country of focus because according to UN reports, Nigeria has the highest number of children that are out of school). Emi has a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics and in Nigeria she has had a lot of experience teaching children from the ages of 2 to 6 in little playgroups. She also has a lot of social capital in Nigeria both governmental, non-governmental and in the educational sector.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We set our target at $10,000 but the truth is, we need to raise as much money as we can to qualify for the Hult Prize 2015 finals competition in New York and our deadline is May 8th, 2015. To learn more about the Hult Prize competition and Clinton initiative, please click on this link: http://www.hultprize.org/en/compete/online-challenge-2015/overview/
  • We have different perks for our donors ranging from customizable branded t-shirts to individuals being able to choose schools they want us to send our cartoons to anywhere in the world.
  • We are also offering the unique opportunity for donors to have a kid of their choice to start as a character in the cartoon since we are still in the process of developing out main characters.
  • If we don't reach our goal we are still going to proceed with the production of these cartoons because we believe we can still use them to make a difference in the lives of children in Nigeria and other African countries.
  • We are offering individuals the opportunity to help in perpetuating a change by investing in the education of slum kids around the world.

The Impact

  • We have estimated that within our first year of implementing our project we would reach 1 million kids in the urban slums of Lagos.
  • These cartoons are being structured according to the Montessori curriculum and they will be distributed freely to schools and religious centers to ensure that we are able to reach as many children as possible.
  • The biggest challenge we'll face in our implementation plan is the Boko Haram crisis in the northern states in Nigeria and in order to bypass this, we hope to partner with television stations in the Nigeria who will broadcast our cartoons. More specifically, NTA (Nigeria Television Authority) being the television network with the widest reach in Nigeria.

Risks & Challenge

The risks we face on the company level is in the production process of our cartoons which is why we have a board of advisors for different backgrounds to complement our shortcomings and ensure we succeed.

Board of Advisors

Francis Glebas (Storyboarder & Animator at Disney. Notable for his work in the numerous Disney classics such as Aladdin, The Lion King, and Ice Age, just name a few. https://www.linkedin.com/pub/francis-glebas/3/939/3a1)

Chris Haroun (Venture Capitalist, Partner at Artis Ventures. Having a vast array of accomplishments in the business field, he launched an investment firm & led private VC investment in Facebook and other emerging tech firms. http://www.linkedin.com/in/charoun)

Cari Guittard (Global Engagement Partners and Corporate Diplomacy, with exprience in international relations, public diplomacy and cyber security. https://www.linkedin.com/in/cariguittard)

Patrick Guerra (Adjunct Professor of Entrepreneurship, Hult International Business School, and Angel Investor. With experience in supply chain management, innovation, strategic and business Planning for early stage ventures. https://www.linkedin.com/pub/patrick-guerra/0/503/1a)

Avary Kent (Co-Founder, Impact IQ. Experience in financial management, business development, and operations.  https://www.linkedin.com/in/avarykent)


Other Ways You Can Help

Apart from your contributions, we are open to receiving help in the following areas:

  • Sharing our campaign with your friends, family, and professional network, by utilizing the Indiegogo share tools.
  • If you are a great story writer or know one please contact us.
  • Any other input you feel will help in making this a success will be highly appreciated.

Chris Haroun (Venture Capitalist, Partner at Artis Ventures. Having a vast array of accomplishments in the business field, he launched an investment firm & led private VC investment in Facebook and other emerging tech firms. http://www.linkedin.com/in/charoun)
Cari Guittard (Global Engagement Partners and Corporate Diplomacy, with exprience in international relations, public diplomacy and cyber security. https://www.linkedin.com/in/cariguittard)
Patrick Guerra (Adjunct Professor of Entrepreneurship, Hult International Business School, and Angel Investor. With experience in supply chain management, innovation, strategic and business Planning for early stage ventures. https://www.linkedin.com/pub/patrick-guerra/0/503/1a)
Avary Kent (Co-Founder, Impact IQ. Experience in financial management, business development, and operations.  https://www.linkedin.com/in/avarykent)

Other Ways You Can Help
 Apart from your contributions, we are open to receiving help in the following areas:  Sharing our campaign with your friends, family, and professional network, by utilizing the Indiegogo share tools. If you are a great story writer or know one please contact us.
Any other input you feel will help in making this a success will be highly appreciated.

story:
Short Summary

The Board of Directors and Capital Campaign Cabinet are proud to announce the receipt of a $500,000 anonymous contribution to the capital campaign and in addition, a $500,000 challenge grant!

$500,000 will be given right away and the remaining $500,000 is in the form of a match.  All contributions or pledges made to the capital campaign before June 30, 2016 will be matched dollar for dollar up to $500,000!  Now is the time to make a contribution, especially if your company will match it.   Tell the MSOW story to your parents, friends, business owners, corporate donors!  Use the attached pledge form today!  Together we can achieve our goal!  Thank you!

About the campaign:

The Montessori School of Waukesha (MSOW) is the oldest (founded 1964) and largest Montessori school in Waukesha County, Wisconsin. The demand for an educational model preparing children for a world where anything is possible has been heard loud and clear by MSOW. Enrollment is nearing capacity, but we want to expand our campus to offer this education to more children. With the purchase of 2 adjacent properties in the past three years, we have gone from a 3 acre to 9 acre campus! Additionally, we are creating a Montessori Training Center to certify new Montessori teachers, as well as share the fundamentals of Montessori with traditionally trained teachers. In 2013, MSOW launched a capital campaign titled: ”Montessori. Education in Action.” Funds raised for these significant initiatives will change the history of Montessori School of Waukesha and Montessori education in Wisconsin. 


What We Need & What You Get

Donations will be used to enhance and grow our program: new classroom materials, and program expansion for science, art and music, all of which will enhance each child’s experience and education. Additionally, donations will be used for a dual purpose lecture hall/auditorium for the school and Montessori Training Center. A performance stage, botanical garden, and a nature trail have already been funded!

·  The capital campaign is designed to complete the goals of the strategic plan for the school. We recognize this will take several million dollars and some time. We are launching an Indiegogo campaign to raise awareness and keep the momentum going in our campaign. 

·  With $75,000 we can begin to make changes to classrooms (preparation for construction) and pay the professionals needed to create this plan (architects, builders, engineers, etc…).

·  Our world is changing faster than ever before. We want the next generation to be prepared to make the world an even better place. Just imagine what could exist even bigger and better than Google or Amazon!

·  If we don’t reach our entire goal here on Indiegogo, we will be sad, but don’t worry as there are always places to use the money within the classrooms for updates and new learning materials. There is great demand for a Montessori training center, so we will expand our offerings in professional development, consulting and the Paraprofessional course that we do now.


The Impact

Become part of a revolution in education! There is a reason more and more public school districts are chartering Montessori schools and incorporating the Montessori methods into their curriculums. The reason is IT WORKS!

·  Thinking outside of the box is a natural thinking pattern for children. Help foster this free thinking and just imagine what could become of the community and the world.

·  World change doesn’t happen overnight. We have to be proactive and begin with the expansion of schools offering a working education. Waukesha County, Wisconsin is very fortunate to have this gem in its midst. Now, let’s work on expanding the school so we can produce more confident innovators for the future.


Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenges are sharing our message and getting funding. We must overcome the incorrect assumptions about Montessori education to gather support. Here are a few of the assumptions we’d like to correct.

1) We are NOT a weird religion or a parochial school

2) While our classrooms are open space models with no desks, it DOES NOT mean there is no structure. Montessori materials are extremely purposeful and children learn at a young age to respect the materials and the work time.

3) We are NOT “a rich white kid’s school.” The diversity of our classrooms is greater than other schools in our area. We value and celebrate diversity. It gives our children a clearer look at the world. We are a private school but have always offered scholarships and currently have district sponsored 4K for Waukesha and Kettle Moraine students.

4) We are not JUST a pre-school. We offer curriculum through 8th grade. Our elementary students consistently score at least 2 grade levels above their chronological age on standardized testing.


Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone can contribute monetarily and we completely understand. We gladly accept elbow-grease with any number of things from landscaping, carpentry, cleaning services, etc… We are open to ideas.

·  We kindly ask that everyone help get the word out about our school and campaign.

·  Please utilize the Indiegogo share tools!

4) We are not JUST a pre-school. We offer curriculum through 8th grade. Our

story:
Why Environmental Education?

Science Camp provides children with an experience that nurtures an appreciation for the natural world in a camp "community" that also develops respect for self and others. The personal competencies developed during science camp carry over to the world back at school and in the home. These include self-identity, self-worth, compassion, contribution, commitment and character. Children who attend science camp typically are transformed by the experience, and parents report their children are more caring, understand the importance of giving, and are more equipped to stand up for what they know is right. These are qualities that will help build a successful nation and an even better world.

Who am I?

I am the superintendent of the Bellevue Union School District (www.busd.org). 

Why am I Doing This?

Our district does not have a foundation to raise funds for extra-curricular activities and events such as Science Camp. Our schools have organized fundraising activities, yet not enough funds are raised to support all of our students. We have four schools, with approximately 275 students in 6th grade who would love to participate in Science Camp.

Where Will the Money Go?

All of the funds will be used to pay for Science Camp registration and transportation of students back and forth to Science Camp.

Each school costs $10,000 to fully fund all 6th graders. If the full amount requested of $40,000 is raised, then all four schools can attend.

What You Get

First and foremost, you will feel good about donating to a worthy cause. All donors will be listed on our web page. With donations of $100 or more, you will receive "thank you" notes from students who attended science camp. For donations of $1000 or more, donors will be invited to be the "principal for a day". For donations of $10,000 or more, donors will be invited to be "superintendent for a day". 

The Impact

Your donation will help our students develop an appreciation of the outdoors and to take care of our earth. As described above, the impact of science camp is widespread and plays out in the lives of students way beyond 6th grade.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you support our cause but are unable to contribute, please consider using the Indiegogo share tools to let others know about our campaign.

Thank you so much.

story:
This fund will go to raise money for Ashley's research for the coral bacteria Montipora White Syndrome, that is infecting Kane'ohe Bay in Hawaii. Funding is the main cause that the project is lacking. We have already raised over $15,000 for the UH (University of Hawaii) Foundation in Ashley's name. This fund continues Ashley's legacy and keeps students working on her project after her passing. 100% of the money raised will go to the Hawaii Institute of Marine Biology in Ashley Smith's name.


Please share on your Facebook and Twitter accounts.


Below in information about Ashley and the Fund.


A St. Charles High School graduate working to find a solution to a coral-killing bacteria in Hawaii died unexpectedly last month during a research trip in Australia.

Ashley Smith was 26. Family members said she felt ill before her death, but they do not yet know the official cause.

Her relatives said marine life, volleyball (she was part of St. Charles High’s state championship team), her friends and being a good older sister were important to her. They also described her as happy, generous and compassionate but said no words can quite summarize what she was like.

“She was destined for big things,” said her aunt Beverly Obrecht. “We knew what she did, and truthfully I’m not sure we knew the magnitude of what she was doing.”

Obrecht was referring to her niece’s work with the Hawaii Institute of Marine Biology. In February, Kane’ohe Bay suffered an outbreak of a disease called Montipora White Syndrome that can kill colonies of coral within weeks. Her research identified the bacteria, her family said.

Ashley Smith received an invitation to do similar work in Australia while working in Hawaii with a visiting researcher from the Australian Institute of Marine Science. She talked with her parents about how to make that happen, said her mother, Barb Smith.

“We did everything in our power to help her,” she said.

And so Ashley Smith planned a two-and-a-half-month trip to Australia. Barb Smith said her daughter died before she got to conduct the research she had planned.

“I was very proud of her,” Barb Smith said. “She followed her passion. … She wanted to make a difference in the sea life.”

Ashley Smith’s infatuation with marine life began at age 2 when, during a trip to Seattle, she reached through a touch tank containing crabs and stingrays, pulled out a starfish and plopped it on her forehead.

“She had no fear, just wonder,” Barb Smith said.

Ashley Smith earned an undergraduate degree in marine biology, a master’s degree in microbiology and was working toward a doctorate degree in marine microbiology.

Additionally, her mother said, Ashley Smith was proud of her scuba diving accomplishments. She was a certified master diver and a research diver, she said.

Ashley Smith planned to return to Hawaii to research the cause of the bacteria outbreak and, if possible, to develop a plan to reverse it, her mother said.

story:
Short Summary

As a preschooler my family said that had very little interest in my surroundings.  I loved certain videos and watched them over and over again.  I had little spoken language.  Naturally, they were concerned and when my mom  mentioned her lack of language and interactions, my aunt suggested that they get some early-childhood testing.  My examiners suggested that I might be autistic.  They recommended some programs and through my participation in them, I was able to start kindergarten and enter first grade with the rest of my classmates. My family tells me that I blossomed into a motivated learner, and I have used that motivation to never stop learning, working my way to a law degree.

 My name is Arianne Gallagher and I am a policy advisor in DC for the federal government. Fortunately, I was never diagnosed with Autism, but so many others aren't so lucky. All of us can probably reach out to our family and friends and find someone who has been affected by Autism, either directly or through their family and friends. We have seen how Autism affects children and adults so deeply and for families supporting children with autism- it is one of the toughest challenges a parent would ever have to face.

I want to help, but I didn't know how, not until I met the great folks from Bike to the Beach DC- a non-profit who works to raise money for Autism research and awareness, including great organizations like Autism Speaks.  Every year this group encourages people to participate in a 100-mile bike ride with a requirement to raise $500 minimum for Autism charities.  I knew it would be difficult but if I could make a difference in the lives of others who are struggling with Autism and their families, I jumped at the chance.  But I need your help to raise the funds for autism charities to take the ride.

A year ago I wouldn't be physically able to do something like this, but I chose to have gastric bypass surgery and work hard to lose weight and keep it off- a year later I have lost 86 pounds and can finally participate in charity events like this- I am greatly looking forward to continue to improve my health with every mile while raising money for autism research and awareness! Doing this means a lot to me personally, and I would greatly appreciate your help!

What I Need & What You Get

  • I need $500 in order to participate in the 100 mile bike ride from DC to Delaware.  All funds go to either Autism Speaks or other autism research and awareness charities. 
  • Any funds raised here will go towards Autism charities
  • You get the satisfaction knowing that your support will help autism research while spreading awareness. If you own a company or business and would like me to wear something with your logo or mention your company on any of my fundraising websites I will be happy to do so (minimum of $50 donation for this)

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to take the ride yourself?  Go here to find out more: http://www.biketothebeach.org/site/c.duIVJdNXKkL2G/b.8515825/k.BE45/Home.htm 

  •  Please help me get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you!


~Arianne Gallagher~

story:
Join our Team for a Better World

Namaste, 

My name is Hanuman Dass and I wish to introduce you to the Dharmic temple School project. Myself and our team at Go Dharmic believes that serving the poor is the best way to serve God.

Educating young village children is one of the best ways we can do this most effectively, so, our plan is to build a small primary school in a poor part of India which fulfills this ambition.

Help us to raise the funds required to build this place of service and join us in our efforts to demonstrate the ideal that serving humanity is serving God.

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign is to fund 50% of the required funds for our project. More than you giving a donation, we want you to join us to help make this dream a reality.  Send me an email at hanumandass@godharmic.com to join the fundraising and awareness effort.

All of the funds donated will go 100% towards the temple project and launching the school for the underprivileged.   There will be full transparency of the spending provided on our website www.godharmic.com

In the Ancient Hindu scripture the Ramayana, Hanuman meets Rama distressed in a forest with no possessions and his wife kidnapped. Hanuman serves Rama with full devotion.  In the same way Hanuman served Rama in the time of need, we seek to serve the needy as non other than God.

This is (as far as we know!) the worlds first Temple school funded largely by online crowd sourcing. It will truly be a wonderful and noble expression of the power of social media to do good in the world!

The Impact

We want this project to make a high impact difference to peoples lives. But we want it all to be in God's name.  Many people say there are too many temples, but we believe if temples were like this then there could never be enough. Inspired by Neem Karoli Baba's simple but profound message, "Love everybody, serve everybody, remember God", we hope hope to make this temple come school a living expression of compassion and love. 

  • This is our chance to collectively practise the philosophy of Hinduism which says that God exists in all. 
  • Education is one of the best ways to improve the quality of opportunity and living for the underprivileged. 
  • We have over 100,000 people on our Go Dharmic community lists and want to inspire as many people as possible to join our team. 

Risks & Challenges

WIth any project like this there are risks and hurdles which we will encounter. This could be not raising enough funds, finding the right teacher at the school, but we will study every possible outcome and act with full responsibility and diligence, and as Swami Vivekananda said, 'do not stop until the goal is reached'.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to contribute financially that is fine, but please do join us by fundraising yourself, or getting in touch for ideas of how to contribute. You can email me on hanumandass@godharmic.com or even call me on +447944899960.

Jai Shri Rama!

Hanuman Dass

This could be not raising enough funds, finding the right teacher at the school, but we will study every possible outcome and act with full responsibility and diligence, and as Swami Vivekananda said, 'do not stop until the goal is reached'.   Other Ways You Can Help If you cannot afford to contribute financially that is fine, but please do join us by fundraising yourself, or getting in touch for ideas of how to contribute. You can email me on hanumandass@godharmic.com or even call me on +447944899960.
Jai Shri Rama!
Hanuman Dass

story:
The Santara Computer: A $100 Mini-Computer with Built-in Projector for Tackling Global Health and Education

The Santara Computer is a revolutionary new computer based on the Rasberry Pi 2 platform. We developed a built-in mini-projector which can project a large image in dim lighting large enough for groups of 15-20 children to see. Combined with health education resources, revolutionary new software which teaches children to read in record time, a built-in library and much more, the Santara Computer has the potential to revolutionize global health and education.

Disease, malnutrition, premature death, and related health issues affect millions of people around the world. In many cases, the solution to these problems is empowerment through education: accessing maternal clinics can reduce death during pregnancy, oral rehydration solution can help address dehydration, simple medications can stop leprosy, etc. If it were just possible for people to obtain and understand health information, then they would have the tools they need to address not only their own issues, but the issues of their communities as well. In order to address health issues, often general education issues like literacy must first be tackled.


Several projects have sought to bridge the health issue / education gap using devices such as tablets, desktop computers, and laptops. However, these suffer from limitations which make them difficult to implement and unsustainable in some cases.


Tablets, laptops, and desktop computers suffer from a key limitation: in most cases one device works with one student. This makes scaling a solution very costly and difficult. In several cases, a group of people may have to crowd around a single device such as a laptop which affects the learning experience.

In other cases, when children have an individual laptop or computer, the classroom interactions are disrupted. The best approach would be to have a single device, which can create a large image, and many children can use and benefit from at the same time, and also interact with the teacher and their peers, rather than just focusing on a single device.

By incorporating a single, large projected display the Santara Computer can address this issue. Instead of having to spend money on several individual devices like computers and tablets, classroom interactions are maintained since all children can work from a single display. As well, only one device is required to teach many children.

Empowering people with the tools to solve local and global problems. 

We believe many health issues can be solved by first addressing basic education needs. We're talking about issues like malnutrition, diarrhea and leprosy. By giving people the tools they need to be part of the solution, we'll tackle these global issues collectively. The Santara Computer will help provide children have the tools they needs to create a healthy home, family and life.

The Santara Computer: Built-in Projector + Solar Charging + Built-in Library + Educational Software

The Santara Computer's built-in projector really sets it apart from other computers. Another key things that distinguishes the Santara Computer from other devices is its incredible flexibility. It can display images using the projector, a television, or a HDMI monitor, it can be powered multiple ways, it's multi-lingual, and it also has multiple ways of connecting to the Internet.

    

The software on the Santara consists of a Linux based operating system (which we've called the Santara OS and which will be open source), which we've customized with a lot of additional services and resources, such as offline translation of basic words and phrases into Hindi, Tamil, Russian, Chinese, Spanish, and other languages. An interesting feature of the Santara Computer is the "printing press." With the printing press, users can print from somewhere in rural India, Kenya, or another country by simply selecting a document to print, picking a printer in Cambridge UK (or somewhere else). The document will be transmitted over the Internet, printed in the UK, and then mailed back to the person who sent it for printing. While the Santara Foundation will initially pay for the shipping costs, we hope to eventually get financial support to make this feature widespread. 

In addition to translation features, the printing press, and operating system tweaks to work with the Santara Computer hardware, there are several other features (illustrated below) which enhance the learning experience. We eventually hope to have an app store where teachers can develop their own content and distribute it online for free, in addition to developing programs using the EduCell programming language.


The Santara Computer was originally developed by Andrew Deonarine, a medical resident in Public Health and Preventative Medicine at the University of British Columbia, and who completed a PhD recently from the University of Cambridge in computational and theoretical biology. During his residency training, Andrew thought that many international and local health issues could be addressed by first addressing basic education, in particular literacy. This lead to the development of EduCell, an educational authoring / programming system that runs on inexpensive cellular phones such as Nokia's S40 platform. EduCell won the Economist Magazine - Innocentive Prize in 2010 which consisted of $10,000. This eventually lead to Andrew becoming a fellow at the Royal Institution of the United Kingdom, where he worked with Royal Institution fellows to develop innovative educational software and technology.

To ensure the success of the Santara Computer, we have spent thousands of pounds producing prototypes, designing hardware and software, and making sure the whole system works well together. We are now entering limited-series production (LSP) models for field testing, particularly in Kenya and India. The prototypes that have been developed so far are illustrated below:

While the Raspberry Pi is a well established platform, our inexpensive projector has brought a vital innovation to the Raspberry Pi community. While previously to work with Raspberry Pis users had to have a television or a monitor, which can often be quite expensive and consume a lot of power, they can now use a mini projector to get a bright image wherever they are. 

The projector built into the Santara Computer is capable of producing an image with a resolution of 640 x 480 pixels. The image can reach up to 50 inches (diagonal) in size, and is visible in dim / evening light. Of course, a vivid image can be seen in a dark room. In the top left image, the Santara software can be used to display an interesting "transparent" or "floating" image which can be very captivating and engaging for children and learners. Additionally, content from large international organisations can easily be imported, adapted, and used in the Santara computer. 

Revolutionary poverty reduction. And you can be part of it.

Several proofs of concepts and prototypes have been built, and we are in the process of field-testing our Mark 3 prototype. But there’s a lot that will go into taking it from prototype to production. And it is going to cost $1 million.


This is obviously an ambitious goal, and the reason why we need $1 million is for the following reasons:

1. We have a lot of collaborators ready to go, but many of them are small and do not have funding: even though the Santara is inexpensive, it's hard to ask a school in a rural, poor village to pay for it. As a result, we are hoping to raise enough funds to get the Santara into as many schools as possible, 1000 at the least.

Right now we have extensive interest in both India and Kenya which we're hoping to capitalise on in the coming weeks an months, but we can only do so with the help of you the donor!

2. In order to keep the unit cost down, we need to purchase large amounts of items: certain supplies, like cameras, storage devices, etc. need to be purchased in batches of 1000 or more in order to get a competitive price for each computer, and keep it under $100. 

3. Significant funds are needed for research and development, both on hardware and also on educational theory: while this technology will seek to augment the classroom, or in some cases, replace the classroom all together, we hope to not only fund the development of new, inexpensive, and innovative technology but also fund research papers into new education techniques and approaches we hope to develop with academics down the road.

4. Software development and translation: while we are developing an extensive set of software, and also integrating a lot of existing software, books, and information from existing sources, often these resources are only available in English. As a result, we're developing a comprehensive translation framework, as well as doing manual translation of a lot of resources. This is very cost-intensive and labour-intensive.

Based on our budget, $1 million will help us with costs associated for software development, logistics, manufacturing and distribution. Some of the dollars raised will go to administration, allowing us to have the right team spearheading this important work. We'll also be setting up offices in three countries and hiring people to train teachers.



By reaching our campaign goal, the Santara Foundation will aim to distribute 1000 computers in three countries. Based on a classroom of 15 people, 1000 computers can educate as many as 15,000 students at any given time!

The final cost of the Santara Computer will be $100.

How we’ll thank you for donating

We know you’re interested in Santara because you want to be part of big change more than getting swag or gadgets in return for your donation. We've put together a few ways we'll show our appreciation for your support (without spending too much of your precious donations on it!)

We’re not the only ones who have good stuff to say about the Santara Computer!

The Santara Computer was conceived of and developed by Andrew Deonarine, a medical doctor, who came up with the idea after researching international health. It grew out of work Andrew did on a previous platform called EduCell, which won the Economist Magazine - Innocentive prize in 2010 for Education. We believe that there is significant potential for the Santara Computer to revolutionise health and education, an opinion shared by others as well:

“The Santara Computer is a sustainable answer to the challenges of computer technology in settings like Awegys School’s where there’s no electricity,” Gretchen Seibert, Director, Mtaala Foundation, Uganda

“Santara's technology has the potential to work with organizations around the world in order to better serve their respective communities,” Susie Marks, Executive Director, Hamomi Children’s Centre


To launch the Santara Computer, we recently had an opening gala on April 9th, 2015 at the Royal Institution of Great Britain. Over 100 people attended the function, and it was a great success! Some photos of the gala presented below. Visitors got to see the Mark 2 in action, and also talk with its inventor Andrew Deonarine, as well as others such as the project lead, lead hardware / software developers, and volunteers.


Get to know the Santara Foundation

We're a Cambridge-based start-up dedicated to addressing global health and education issues through novel technology. Our initial project is the Santara Computer. The Santara Foundation was founded by employees at Onto.it Software, a company specializing in advanced search engines, drug discovery and advanced data modelling. The Santara Foundation is a registered non-profit in the United Kingdom, limited by guarantee.

We have two co-founders, one dedicated employee, and a small team of developers and consultants (many who have donated countless of their own hours working on Santara Computer). We’re excited for you to meet these passionate game changers.

There’s not enough room on this site to list the accomplishments of Andrew Deonarine, Canadian inventor of the Santara Computer. (You can learn more on our website.) Andrew recently graduated with a PhD from Cambridge, and has a passion for medicine, public health, health education, software and hardware development.

Jesper Nissen is a Cambridge University graduate and has more than five years experience consulting and working in biotechnology and business roles. He loves to travel and has visited schools in Kenya to see first-hand where the Santara Computer will go.

Annabel Amodia-Bidakowska is the project lead for Santara Computer. With a background in Education and Developmental Psychology from Girton College at Cambridge University, Annabel is motived by the potential to change lives of thousands of people around the world. 

Other Contributors

Peter Deonarine, Andrew’s cousin, is the Santara Computer's lead hardware designer. He’s spent countless hours sawing, gluing and drilling to make Santara’s case just the right size and weight. (He did a happy dance when we got our first 3D printer.)

Denis Lobanov is our software engineer who is a keen motorcyclist and has a passion for programming. He can be credited for working on the core linux system functionality and creating a build-system for when the Santara Computer hits the production line.

Our lead developer, Venkat Pasumarti, is a big cricket fan with a knack for web applications. With a Bachelors of Computer Engineering and MSc. Computer Science under his belt, he’s excited to be working on a smart, innovative way of educating children.

Vinoth, our content provider, is originally from Chennai, India. He says the greatest thing about working on the Santara Computer is 'it gives me an opportunity to give something back to my community.’ 

Wanlu Wang has been focusing on the configuration and development of Raspberry Pi in the Santara Computer. While his master dissertation is related to video processing on the the Raspberry Pi , his specialty in the kitchen is a fried shrimp omelette. 

Weiyan Xiang is one of our software developers. When he's not developing apps and the core API for Santara or talking in JavaScript, you’ll find him jogging to Bruno Mars tunes. When asked why he enjoys working for Santara he responded simply by saying,‘this is the most creative project I have ever seen.’ 

Sarah Marshall is one of our two consultants (both of whom are named Sarah!). When she’s not writing tweets for us, you’ll find her cuddled up with a good book. 

Sarah Woods our Canadian consultant, is a passionate person with a big heart for doing good in the world. If you encounter any typos on this page, she’ll take the heat. 

He’s got a soft spot for spaghetti carbonara and Ghostpoet’s Off Peak Dreams is the top song on his play list. Alexander Petkoglo is our Russian artist and lead designer and frontend developer for our website. 

Haikal Pribadi has done some seriously cool things – like developed a complete open-source robot driver that was picked up for research by NASA. He’s a Clare College graduate from Cambridge University and heads up development and technology for the Santara Computer.

The Santara Computer was built from a deep passion and desire within to make positive change in the world. It’s from that same place we want to say... THANK YOU.

With our novel hardware and software, testing sites in various countries, and an enthusiastic team, the only missing part is you! Thank you for taking interest in the Santara Computer and considering being part of the change we want to see around these important global issues.

If we’ve missed something or you have more questions please get in touch! You can also check us out on our website.
